Article 102
An act that a person with qualified legal capacity performs as an agent of another person may not be rescinded on the grounds of qualified legal capacity;provided, however, that this does not apply to an act performed by a person with qualified legal capacity as a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity.
t2: A minor may not be an agent.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is that a minor may not be an agent.

Rule 1: The term "agent" refers to a person who acts on behalf of another person, known as the principal, and has the authority to make decisions and perform actions that affect the principal's legal rights and obligations.

Rule 2: Under the law, a minor is a person who has not yet reached the age of majority, which is generally 18 years old. Minors are considered to have limited legal capacity and are generally not allowed to enter into contracts or make legal decisions.

Application: Based on the legal definitions of "agent" and "minor," it can be concluded that a minor may not act as an agent because they do not have the legal capacity to make decisions on behalf of another person.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis that a minor may not be an agent is true based on the legal reasoning approach.

Article 608
(1) If a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing which ought to be borne by the lessor, the lessee may immediately demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor.
(2) If the lessee has incurred beneficial expenses with respect to the leased thing, the lessor must reimburse those expenses on termination of the lease in compliance with the provisions of Article 196, paragraph (2);provided, however, that the court may, at the lessor's request, grant a reasonable period of time for the reimbursement of the same.
t2: In cases where a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased Thing in order to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the subject, the lessee can wait for the end of the lease and demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is that a lessee can wait for the end of the lease and demand reimbursement from the lessor for necessary expenses incurred in order to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the subject.

Rule 1: Under Article 608(1), a lessee can demand immediate reimbursement from the lessor for necessary expenses that the lessee has defrayed with respect to the leased thing which ought to be borne by the lessor.

Rule 2: Under Article 608(2), if the lessee has incurred beneficial expenses with respect to the leased thing, the lessor must reimburse those expenses on termination of the lease in compliance with the provisions of Article 196, paragraph (2).

Application: Based on the legal provisions in Article 608, it can be concluded that the hypothesis is true. If a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing in order to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the subject, the lessee can either demand immediate reimbursement from the lessor or wait until the termination of the lease and demand reimbursement from the lessor, in compliance with the provisions of Article 196, paragraph (2).

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis that a lessee can wait for the end of the lease and demand reimbursement from the lessor for necessary expenses incurred in order to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the subject is true based on the legal reasoning approach.

Article 704
A beneficiary in bad faith must return the benefit received together with interest thereon. In such cases, if any damage still remains, the beneficiary is liable to compensate for this.

Article 715
(1) A person that employs another person for a business undertaking is liable to compensate for damage inflicted on a third party by that person's employees with respect to the execution of that business;provided, however, that this does not apply if the employer exercised reasonable care in appointing the employee or in supervising the business, or if the damage could not have been avoided even if the employer had exercised reasonable care.
(2) A person that supervises a business on behalf of the employer also has the liability referred to in the preceding paragraph.
(3) The provisions of the preceding two paragraphs do not preclude the employer or supervisor from exercising their right to reimbursement against the employee.
t2: The employer is released from his/her liability in cases when proof is provided that the employer made proper care regarding the appointment and supervision of the employee.
ChatGPT_output:
Thesis: The hypothesis is that the employer is released from liability in cases when proof is provided that the employer exercised proper care regarding the appointment and supervision of the employee.

Rule 1: Under Article 715(1), a person who employs another person for a business undertaking is liable to compensate for damage inflicted on a third party by that person's employees in the execution of that business.

Rule 2: However, under Article 715(1), the employer is not liable if they exercised reasonable care in appointing the employee or in supervising the business, or if the damage could not have been avoided even if the employer had exercised reasonable care.

Application: Based on the legal provisions in Article 715, it can be concluded that the hypothesis is true. The employer can be released from liability if they can provide proof that they exercised proper care in appointing and supervising the employee, or if the damage could not have been avoided even if the employer had exercised reasonable care.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis that the employer is released from liability in cases when proof is provided that the employer exercised proper care regarding the appointment and supervision of the employee is true based on the legal reasoning approach.
